vitamins.title: Vitamins in Human Body
vitamins.summary: Essential micronutrients required for normal metabolic function, growth, and overall health, typically obtained through diet. They are vital for diverse bodily processes, including energy production, immune defense, and cellular repair, playing a crucial role in preventing various diseases and maintaining overall well-being.

children.title: Dietary Sources
children.summary: Various food sources that provide essential vitamins to the body. A balanced diet rich in diverse foods ensures adequate vitamin intake for optimal health.

children.title: Fruits & Vegetables
children.summary: Fresh produce like citrus fruits, leafy greens, and colorful vegetables are excellent sources of vitamins A, C, K, and folate.

children.title: Meat & Dairy
children.summary: Animal products including meat, fish, eggs, and dairy are primary sources of B-complex vitamins, especially B12, and vitamin D.

children.title: Grains & Nuts
children.summary: Whole grains, nuts, and seeds provide vitamin E, B vitamins (thiamin, niacin), and other essential nutrients.

children.title: Sunlight & Fortified
children.summary: Vitamin D is synthesized through sun exposure, while many foods are fortified with vitamins A, D, and B12.

children.title: Health Impact & Balance
children.summary: Maintaining adequate vitamin levels is crucial, as both deficiencies (hypovitaminosis) and excesses (hypervitaminosis) can lead to health problems. These imbalances can manifest in a range of symptoms and conditions, significantly affecting long-term health and quality of life if not addressed.

children.title: Deficiency
children.summary: Vitamin deficiencies can cause serious health issues: scurvy (Vitamin C), rickets (Vitamin D), beriberi (B1), and night blindness (Vitamin A).

children.title: Excess
children.summary: Hypervitaminosis, especially with fat-soluble vitamins (A, D, E, K), can be toxic and cause symptoms ranging from nausea to organ damage.

children.title: Key Bodily Roles
children.summary: Vitamins serve as cofactors for enzymes, antioxidants, and regulators of gene expression, playing essential roles in numerous physiological processes.

children.title: Bone Health
children.summary: Vitamins D and K work together with calcium to maintain strong bones and prevent osteoporosis.

children.title: Immune System Support
children.summary: Vitamins A, C, D, and E support immune function, helping the body fight infections and diseases.

children.title: Energy Metabolism
children.summary: B-complex vitamins are crucial for converting food into energy, supporting cellular metabolism and ATP production.

children.title: Antioxidant Protection
children.summary: Vitamins C and E act as antioxidants, neutralizing free radicals and protecting cells from oxidative damage.

children.title: Vitamin Classification
children.summary: Vitamins are primarily classified based on their solubility in fats or water, which dictates their absorption, storage, and excretion mechanisms in the body. This fundamental distinction influences dietary intake recommendations, potential for toxicity, and how they are utilized by different physiological systems.

children.title: Fat-Soluble Vitamins
children.summary: Vitamins A, D, E, and K are fat-soluble, stored in liver and fatty tissues. They require dietary fat for absorption and can accumulate to toxic levels.

children.title: Vitamin A
children.summary: Essential for vision, immune function, and skin health. Found in liver, carrots, and sweet potatoes.

children.title: Vitamin D
children.summary: The 'sunshine vitamin' crucial for calcium absorption and bone health. Synthesized in skin upon UV exposure.

children.title: Vitamin E
children.summary: A powerful antioxidant that protects cell membranes. Found in nuts, seeds, and vegetable oils.

children.title: Vitamin K
children.summary: Essential for blood clotting and bone metabolism. Found in leafy greens and fermented foods.

children.title: Water-Soluble Vitamins
children.summary: B-complex vitamins and Vitamin C dissolve in water, are not stored long-term, and excess is excreted through urine. Regular intake is essential.

children.title: Vitamin C
children.summary: Critical for collagen synthesis, immune function, and iron absorption. Found abundantly in citrus fruits and berries.

children.title: B-Complex Vitamins
children.summary: Eight B vitamins (B1-B12) that work together in energy metabolism, nervous system function, and red blood cell formation.

software-architecture.title: Software Architecture Patterns
software-architecture.summary: Fundamental approaches to organizing software systems that have stood the test of time. These patterns provide templates for solving common architectural problems and help create maintainable, scalable applications.

children.title: Monolithic Architecture
children.summary: A traditional unified model where all components are interconnected and interdependent, deployed as a single unit.

children.title: Layered Pattern
children.summary: Organizes code into horizontal layers (presentation, business, data) with each layer only communicating with adjacent layers.

children.title: MVC Pattern
children.summary: Model-View-Controller separates data, presentation, and user input handling into three interconnected components.

children.title: Distributed Architecture
children.summary: Systems where components are spread across multiple computers, communicating over a network to achieve common goals.

children.title: Microservices
children.summary: Decomposes applications into small, independent services that communicate via APIs, each deployable separately.

children.title: API Gateway
children.summary: A single entry point that routes requests to appropriate microservices, handling cross-cutting concerns.

children.title: Service Mesh
children.summary: Infrastructure layer handling service-to-service communication with features like load balancing and encryption.

children.title: Event-Driven
children.summary: Components communicate through events, enabling loose coupling and real-time responsiveness.

children.title: Pub/Sub Pattern
children.summary: Publishers emit events to topics; subscribers receive events they're interested in without direct coupling.

children.title: Event Sourcing
children.summary: State changes are stored as a sequence of events, enabling full audit trails and temporal queries.

children.title: Serverless Architecture
children.summary: Cloud-native approach where the cloud provider manages infrastructure, and developers focus purely on code.

children.title: Functions as a Service
children.summary: Individual functions triggered by events, automatically scaled and billed per execution.

children.title: Backend as a Service
children.summary: Pre-built backend services like authentication, databases, and storage accessed via APIs.

machine-learning.title: Machine Learning Fundamentals
machine-learning.summary: A branch of artificial intelligence enabling systems to learn from data, identify patterns, and make decisions with minimal human intervention. ML powers everything from recommendation systems to autonomous vehicles.

children.title: Supervised Learning
children.summary: Learning from labeled training data to make predictions on unseen data. The algorithm learns a mapping function from input to output.

children.title: Classification
children.summary: Predicting discrete categories or classes. Examples include spam detection, image recognition, and medical diagnosis.

children.title: Decision Trees
children.summary: Tree-structured models that split data based on feature values, easy to interpret and visualize.

children.title: Neural Networks
children.summary: Layered networks of artificial neurons that can learn complex patterns through backpropagation.

children.title: Regression
children.summary: Predicting continuous numerical values. Used for price prediction, demand forecasting, and trend analysis.

children.title: Linear Regression
children.summary: Fits a linear relationship between features and target variable. Simple, interpretable, and fast.

children.title: Polynomial Regression
children.summary: Captures non-linear relationships by adding polynomial terms to the feature set.

children.title: Unsupervised Learning
children.summary: Discovering hidden patterns in unlabeled data without explicit guidance on what to look for.

children.title: Clustering
children.summary: Grouping similar data points together. Used for customer segmentation, anomaly detection, and data compression.

children.title: K-Means
children.summary: Partitions data into K clusters by minimizing within-cluster variance. Fast and scalable.

children.title: Hierarchical Clustering
children.summary: Creates a tree of clusters through successive merging or splitting, no need to specify K.

children.title: Dimensionality Reduction
children.summary: Reducing the number of features while preserving important information for visualization and efficiency.

children.title: PCA
children.summary: Principal Component Analysis finds orthogonal directions of maximum variance in the data.

children.title: t-SNE
children.summary: Preserves local structure for visualization of high-dimensional data in 2D or 3D.

children.title: Reinforcement Learning
children.summary: Learning through interaction with an environment, receiving rewards or penalties for actions taken.

children.title: Q-Learning
children.summary: Model-free algorithm that learns action-value functions to find optimal policies.

children.title: Policy Gradient
children.summary: Directly optimizes the policy by following gradients of expected reward.
